Line 4: Line 4:
In April, 2011, after the leak of Windows 8 build 7850<ref>http://www.engadget.com/2011/04/13/windows-8-leaked-caught-looking-a-lot-like-windows-7/</ref>, some users noticed that those builds included a program called "Portable Workspace Creator", indicating it was intended to create bootable USB drives of Windows 8.<ref>http://www.winrumors.com/windows-8-portable-workspace-allows-you-to-run-windows-from-a-usb-device/</ref><ref>http://www.engadget.com/2011/04/15/windows-8-to-feature-usb-runnable-portable-workspaces-sales-of/</ref>
In April, 2011, after the leak of Windows 8 build 7850<ref>http://www.engadget.com/2011/04/13/windows-8-leaked-caught-looking-a-lot-like-windows-7/</ref>, some users noticed that those builds included a program called "Portable Workspace Creator", indicating it was intended to create bootable USB drives of Windows 8.<ref>http://www.winrumors.com/windows-8-portable-workspace-allows-you-to-run-windows-from-a-usb-device/</ref><ref>http://www.engadget.com/2011/04/15/windows-8-to-feature-usb-runnable-portable-workspaces-sales-of/</ref>
â
Later, in September 2011 Microsoft officialy announced ''Windows To Go'' at the [http://www.buildwindows.com/ Build Conference], and distributed bootable USB Flash drives, with 32GB of capacity, with Windows To Go pre-installed.
+
Later, in September 2011 Microsoft officialy announced ''Windows To Go'' at the [http://www.buildwindows.com/ Build Conference], and distributed bootable USB Flash drives, with 32GB of capacity, with Windows To Go pre-installed.<ref>http://www.zdnet.co.uk/blogs/zdnet-uk-first-take-10013312/windows-8-windows-to-go-10024384/</ref>
